physDesc.p: This letter is two pages long. On the first page, “Poetry (Monroe)” is written in pencil at the top. The other page has typed H.M. with the corresponding page number in the top left corner and the date (2/28/16) in the top right corner. On the second page, there is faint text on the page at the top. The text is large and mirrored on the opposite side of the page, It reads, “BERKSHIRE LINEN”.

div.p: Your letter of February 25th came this morning. $60.00 will be all right for “"e;Off the Turnpike. I see your point about bargain rates, and what you offer will be all right.

I saw in "e;The Times"e; yesterday that your "Anthology"e; was coming out next Wednesday, but I imagine from your letter that it cannot be coming so soon. I think myself that "Patterns" and "Red Slippers" would be better for me than "The Coal Picker" and "The Blockhead" – I really don't want "The Blockhead", a I wrote you; and although I like "The Coal Picker" well enough, still I think the other two would be better. Of course, I understand that you cannot arrange exactly; but I should like to think these two to go in, as long as you do not want "Lead Soldiers".

We have given you a fine send-off in "Some Imagist Poets 1916" – not in the "Preface", but in the acknowledgements. It did not go well in the "Preface", as the "Preface" was entirely taken up with matters of technical discussion. But we have given you a whole sentence, and have said how you were the first person to publish imagist poems, how you discovered and have ever since encouraged Imagist poets.

I am glad you liked my article in "The Poetry Journal. See you soon now, and please put those two I have
mentioned in your "Anthology", no matter what else you leave out.
div.postscript: P.S. "Six French Poets" has gone through its first edition, and we are hurrying out another as quickly as possible! Less than three months!!!
